condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: -Total funds donated to implement development projects - Number of projects supported and implemented through the donations -Number of Lebanese expatriate organizations and individuals signed up as ‘friends of Live Lebanon’ on the website or on the Facebook Group - Number of visits to the website -Number of workshops/events arranged worldwide under the name of or in association with Live Lebanon -number of volunteers involved with the promotion of LIVE LEBANON

comment.narrative: -No nationwide, formal, neutral and apolitical structure/channel for Lebanese Diaspora to be engaged in the support of local communities in the most deprived areas of the country -Remittances are mainly given as private donations to individuals -No online system to channel remittances collectively for developmental purposes
At least 5 community based projects are implemented At least 1 partnerships with private sector are developed At least two events are executed to ensure Live Lebanon project visibility

Live Lebanon achievements 2019 Moto-Ambulance Campaign: Traffic is the main barrier to providing prompted and efficient Emergency Medical Services. It takes an average of half an hour for ambulances to reach their destination, which delays CPR and the first-aid support needed, decreasing the chances of survival in many cases. Lebanon suffers from a high number of road accidents that happens every year, causing many fatalities and injuries. According to the WHO, deaths per 100K people in Lebanon is 22.6, which is around 1,088 deaths and 12,340 injuries per year. According to the World Bank, the direct estimated loss is 1.2B USD. The Moto Ambulance project provides an innovative solution to the rapid response problem, especially in highly condensed areas. Motorcycles equipped with first-aid kits and trained paramedics arrive before the regular ambulance to stabilize injured people and increase their chances of survival. The Moto Ambulances will not rule out the role of regular ambulances. Any time an accident occurs, both the motorcycle and the ambulance will be dispatched.
UNDP and Bank Audi launched the Moto-Ambulance campaign on April 24, 2019 in partnership with LBCI, the National Road Safety Council, Champs fund, the Ministry of Interior. Goodwill Ambassadors Ghaleb Farha and Saada Fakhry funded six fully equipped medical bikes and Bank Audi committed to funding 50 other bikes. So far 16 bikes were distributed to the following Civil Sixteen Defense Stations: Jdeide, Tohwita, Ras Beirut, Cola, Jouniyeh, borj El Barajneh, Tripoli, Zahle, Saida, Tyr, Jbeil, Aley, Batroun, Damour, Baalbeck, Hadath. A national campaign was launched on Billboards, TV, Radio, press and social media. So far over 350 emergency missions were conducted in many areas in Lebanon with an average response time of 5 min saving many lives in the process.
Cedar Coin: The Cedar Coin project aims at developing a crypto currency to fund development projects in Lebanon. This coin will be an incentive to increase the number of investors connecting the individuals and private sector in implementing development projects in Lebanon. Cedar coin would be an additional asset on the new Live Lebanon platform, enabling diaspora to invest in reforestation, nature conservation, solar energy, social entrepreneurship, health and development projects. The project is in its final stages prior to the official launch. The design and issuance of the cedar coin using blockchain technology has been completed. The light paper for the development of the coin has been finalized in addition to the website development and design. Initial partners have been selected and we are currently working on the mechanism of payment and implementation of the pilot project. The initial phase of the project launch will focus on reforestation. Warak Beirut: “Warak Beirut” Phase I is completed. On April 24, 2018, the project was launched by the Prime Minister. In June 2018, the project started procurement and operation. During the first phase of the project, 38 public institutions in 77 buildings were covered. Around 48.5 tons of paper and cardboard were collected in phase I only. The project submitted a financial and narrative report to the Municipality which is showing interest in investing in Phase II of the campaign.
Ali Nahri – Building a bridge: “Ali El-Nahri” is a village in Bekaa surrounded by four other villages. Given its central location, it is a cross section for all commuters in the area, which is causing a major traffic problem. On top of that, the commercial crowded area is the only passage for all cars and trucks. The current situation is causing blocked roads and leaving passengers stranded for hours sometimes. Despite the fact that the municipality dispatched many police officers to smoothen the traffic flow, the situation requires more drastic measures such creating exits by building roads from the southern part of Ali El Nahri. The municipality has already started building a new road in place, yet the bridge execution is a must to complete it since it crosses the path of a river. Phase I: 8 meter bridge was built with retaining walls on each side making it safer and easier for vehicles to use this path, decreasing the traffic on the main road. Phase II: Metal Fence on the whole bridge and the retaining walls along with a pavement on both sides of the bridge for safety of pedestrians.
At least 2 crowd funding activities are implemented At least 1 partnership with private sector / individual is developed

Together As One Live Lebanon supported RBAS “Solidarity Against COVID-19: Together As One” regional crowdfunding campaign which took place in 7 COs:
- Syria: Un-silence my world: Supporting Syrian students with disabilities by providing laptops and free internet connectivity. - PAPP: Tensounash: Supporting 33 local Palestinian informal businesses - Djibouti: Rising Djibouti: support 200,000 vulnerable persons, 50,000 self-employed and small business owners by providing grants and materials. - Egypt: Kemamah: Support women in Upper Egypt who are producing masks to fight COVID-19, in partnership with the Egypt Foundation for Integral Develop - Morocco: Bringing school back to children: provide tablets and Internet connectivity to vulnerable students - Somalia: Protect displaced families: Providing locally produced masks, soap and sanitizer to people in camps.
- Lebanon: Mask Your Hero Live Lebanon managed to raise fund for the campaign in Lebanon to procure PPEs to the civil defense. Around 36,000 items were procured and delivered.
Live Lebanon provided technical support and training for colleagues in the mentioned COs Live Lebanon helped with the negotiations with BERA to reduce the GMS to 3%. Live Lebanon provided technical support for the COs by administering the campaigns on classy.org. UNDP.Give official crowdfunding platform. Live Lebanon helped design the regional and the COs campaigns. Live Lebanon helped recruiting three ICs (coordinator, SM expert, graphic designer) Live Lebanon supported in designing, developing and administering the web platform: https://togetherasone.co The amount raised was 700K USD
PWD Campaign Live Lebanon designed a crowdfunding campaign to support people with disabilities as part of a larger initiative within UNDP Building an Inclusive and Accessible Lebanon Initiative https://give.undp.org/pwd Live Lebanon managed to secure online donations and a larger contribution through one of the GWAs to procure assistive devices to PWDs
TADAMON Live Lebanon supported IRH in implementing Tadamon “NGO empowerment for poverty reduction program”. In 2020, 7 priority countries were selected: Lebanon, Somalia, Indonesia, Kazakhistan, Turkey, Morocco and Tunisia. Live Lebanon supported in the mapping exercise for CSOs in those countries which resulted in 774 CSOs signing up to the platform. Live Lebanon supported in designing and developing Tadamon aggregating platform: https://tadamon.community Live Lebanon contributed to 7 introductory webinars with partners and CSOs and organized a webinar in BDD for 135 NGOs
Crowdfunding Academy Live Lebanon secured 25K USD from ISDB to establish a crowdfunding academy in Lebanon. The crowdfunding academy will provide capacity building for CSOs. Live Lebanon also contributed to the development of the digital crowdfunding academy on Kaya platform. Live Lebanon launched a call for proposal for CSOs and secured 140 K USD as grants for the selected ones.
Moto Ambulance Delivery of additional 10 bikes and first aid kit to the civil defense to cover large cities. More than 800 missions were conducted until now. Delivery of advanced firefighting equipment: 6 firefighting backpacks.
Impact Investment: Supported by the EU through the DLT4EU program, Live Lebanon completed a POC for impact investment using Solar PV. The first pilot project will be launched in April 2021,
Live Lebanon has expanded its pool of GWAs by adding a new GWA Ramzi Haidar. We have also secured 90% of our running cost from IRH.
